children.subject: @10790 I don't have an answer to your original question, but I want you to be aware that PNP rules around EECS are very strict unless you are pretty much done with the major.

The answer is: it depends. 

The general rule of thumb I got from talking with people is that you really shouldn't be P/NPing a math class if you're interested in CS grad school is if you're taking an analysis class. As an example, I know for statistics the admissions committee looks at your performance in a class like Math 104 as a measure of your mathematical ability so you need to take it for a letter grade. 

Classes like graph theory, number theory, linear algebra, and others that have obvious CS importance really should also be taken for a grade. Others, like abstract algebra, set theory, can probably be taken P/NP without any issue. 

For statistics, I'm pretty certain that there isn't a course that you can take P/NP without issue, especially if you're interested in ML since there's a significant amount of overlap.

history.content:
Hi,

I'm a junior EECS major interested in going to grad school. I'm going to have a pretty busy semester in the spring (TAing a class, taking 189, and another EECS tech), but would like to take a class in the math or statistics department PNP out of interest. Is PNPing a class like this looked down upon for grad school? I don't want to overload myself, but would still like to take a course.

Thanks!
history.subject: PNPing a Math or Stat Class
